text.headline: From 0 to £89 million pounds: the Most expensive Player transfers in football history
text.text:
by Alessandro Barilaro and Jonathan Pertile

Football is a game replete with money. Sponsorship, Television deals, merchandising; the copious amount of currency fills world football; and it's all circulated in a market where players are constantly moving. In order for a player to move, one club must bid a certain amount of money; the player's parent club must accept, and the deal then moves onward. All of this is compounded under what's called the Transfer Market; a market where players are constantly moving from one club to another.
With more and more money injected into the game at any one point; players continue to cost more and more. Here, we delve into just how much money permeates the game of football via the five most expensive transfers of all time. 

As respected author of 9 books on Liverpool Football Club, and founder of Transfer Price Index (a website that specialises in analysing the transfer market) Paul Tomkins states; while these represent the most significant outlays of money ever spent on a player; they're not the best deals ever done. In fact, often the best deals involved these players; such as how Tomkins says; "Manchester United’s purchase of Cristiano Ronaldo has to go down as the best bit of business. He cost a reasonable fee for his age [£12 million pounds], but eventually he repaid that with title-winning performances and then left for Madrid for a world-record fee [£80 million pounds]." The trend is something that all these deals share; as Paul states; "I think these are the ideal transfers: buy low, get exceptional performances for a number of years and sell incredibly high."

He also demonstrates just how colossal the amount of money in football really is; saying "UK retail inflation (the average cost of a product as covered by the Retail Price Index) hasn’t even doubled since 1992; whereas the average price of a transfer is currently 13 times what it was 24 years ago, and that’s before taking this past summer into account [When Paul Pogba moved for £89 million]. In the past two or three years we’re talking about the average price of a PL footballer doubling."

But see for yourself; here are the five most expensive transfers in world football; to show just how much money pervades the world of football.

text.headline: Paul Pogba: UNder INvestigation
text.text:
Paul Pogba's family was neither poor nor rich during Pogba's childhood; they lived on the outskirts of Roissy-en-Brie which is approximately 23 kilometres away from Paris. Pogba has two elder brothers who are also football players: Mathias plays for Sparta Rotterdam in the Dutch Eredivisie and Florentin represents Saint-Étienne in Ligue 1 French football. 

The greatest obstacle facing Pogba was away from the football pitch. On 7th October 2009, Pogba joined Manchester United despite being only 16 years of age. United were at the pinnacle of English football, under their famous manager Sir Alex Ferguson. However, Pogba's transfer was subject to an intensive investigation conducted by football's governing body: Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA). Le Havre alleged United offered Pogba's family financial inducements in order to secure Pogba's transfer. United considered suing Le Havre based on what they considered to be false allegations. FIFA later cleared United and Pogba of any wrongdoing.

text.headline: Paul Pogba: Forced to Find a New home in Italy
text.text:
Paul Pogba excelled in Manchester United's youth academy; providing a key spark to their 10th Youth Cup title win in 2011. When he was promoted to United’s first XI, Pogba’s chances to impress were few and far between. Pogba played in the midfield, the same position Paul Scholes and Ryan Giggs played in (these two were considered to be amongst the best players in the English Premier League). United’s manager, Sir Alex Ferguson also had a huge falling out with Pogba’s football agent, Mino Raiola. "Our first meeting was a fiasco. He [Pogba's agent] and I were like oil and water," Ferguson said in his autobiography, Leading.

Pogba signed a four-year contract with Serie A giants Juventus in Turin, Italy on 3rd August 2012. Ironically his transfer fee was only just under £1 million; a vast difference to his later transfer fee. Pogba cemented himself as one of the best players in the world at Juventus. While at Juventus, he won multiple Serie A titles and took France to the final of the European Championships. Heralded as the most promising midfielder in world football; any move to pry Pogba away from Turin would have to be astronomical in value. And so it was.

text.headline: Paul Pogba: "The Market has become crazy"
text.text:
José Mourinho, manager of Manchester United, targeted four specialists for his side: a midfielder, defender, striker and winger. Mourinho always had Paul Pogba on his shortlist of players to buy, even when he was managing Chelsea. Despite certain media commentators being shocked by the £89 million pound transfer to bring Pogba back to Old Trafford, former manager of Manchester United Sir Alex Ferguson was supportive of the move. After making his name in Turin, Pogba returned to the place where it all began.

Much to the delight of United supporters, the first game upon his return against Southampton was impressive, giving a clear indication of why they had spent £89 million pounds. Clearly Pogba was a much improved player at 23 years of age than he was five years ago. "The market has become crazy. I just know he is a big player that is going, for sure, to be important for a big club like Manchester United," Mourinho said.

text.headline: Gareth Bale: Small BEGINNINGS
text.text:
Gareth Bale is a sports icon in his home country of Wales, but previous to him there was hardly anyone Bale could point at and tell his family: “I want to follow in this Welshman’s footsteps in football.” There was fellow Welshman and former Manchester United player Ryan Giggs who happened to be Bale’s football hero, but Wales at the time was not a competitive football team. Bale would become the man who changed that.

Bale has always been a superb athlete. As a 14-year-old, Bale ran the 100 metre sprint in just over 11 seconds, and he's considered to be one of the world’s fastest footballers. Despite being only 16 years of age, Bale was the second youngest player to ever play for Southampton (a team who play in the English Premier League). Initially there was doubt as to whether Southampton would offer Bale a placement due to his lack of height: 168 centimetres. Fortunately Bale’s quality as a footballer stood out and he also happened to have had a huge growth spurt. Bale is now a 183 centimetre-tall winger, who is renowned for his prowess on the ball.

text.headline: Gareth Bale: overcoming severe injuries
text.text:
Gareth Bale made 45 appearances for Southampton, scoring 5 goals in the process. On 25th May 2007, Bale signed a four-year contract with Tottenham Hotspur to further advance his career with a higher quality team in England. Bale had a rough start though at Tottenham; suffering ligament damage to his right ankle. When he returned to the squad, he was unable to break into the first team.

In June 2009, Bale underwent surgery once again, this time for a knee injury which sidelined him for over two months. Bale’s career looked to be stagnating as injuries disrupted his development and experience in the English Premier League. It was after a lengthy four years of playing for Tottenham that Bale was finally able to showcase his abilities and make his mark. Bale achieved both the Professional Footballers' Association (PFA) Players’ Player of the Year Award and the Young Player of the Year Award simultaneously on 28 April 2013; announcing himself as one of the world's best young footballers.

media.caption: Paul Pogba's recent £89 million transfer has been all the rage, but his true value will only be finalised in the years to come. It's the right time to analyse whether Gareth Bale was worth the £85 million Real Madrid paid for him in 2013, with football reporter Michael Thompson.
media.credit: Jonathan Pertile interviewing Michael Thompson (Football Reporter for MFootball).

text.headline: Gareth Bale: succeeding outside of his comfort zone
text.text:
On the opening day of September 2013, Real Madrid paid a stunning £85 million for Gareth Bale on a six-year deal. Real Madrid have been very successful during Bale’s tenure with them, winning two UEFA Champions League titles. Bale found it hard though to adjust to a different culture, “I feel like it has taken time to settle in and learn the language,” Bale said.

Bale may have taken a while to adjust but he formed a potent attacking trio alongside Karim Benzema and Cristiano Ronaldo. Bale proved his sublime football skills in Spain, possessing both the stamina and speed to give opposition defenders nightmares. No Welsh football player has superseded the performances Bale has displayed thus far; a testament to the fee that was paid for him.

text.headline: Cristiano Ronaldo: Poverty and expulsion
text.text:
Cristiano Ronaldo dos Santos Aveiro grew up in a poverty-stricken family in Funchal, Madeira in Portugal. He was blessed, however, with a footballing talent which bellied his modest upbringing. His father, José Dinis Aveiro, was an alcoholic who died from a liver condition disease at the age of 52. However, his father introduced him to football formally when Ronaldo was eight years of age. During this period of time, Ronaldo represented Andorinho, an amateur football team where his father was also the kit man. Ronaldo loved football, even when he had undergone laser surgery due to being diagnosed with tachycardia (a heartbeat greater than normal) he was back training within a few days of the operation.

Despite once being expelled from school, Ronaldo has since sculpted his once uncontrollable anger into becoming one of the most competitive sportsmen in the world. A lot of Ronaldo's football skills (mental and physical) can be traced back to his birthplace in Funchal, Maideira in Portugal.

text.headline: Cristiano Ronaldo: The THEATre of Dreams
text.text:
Sir Alex Ferguson, previously the manager of a resurgent Manchester United football club, was the most prominent figure in launching Ronaldo’s career. Ronaldo has described Ferguson as “my father in sport.” Ferguson immediately warmed to Ronaldo in August 2003, when United was defeated by Sporting CP in a warm-up game to the upcoming season. Ronaldo starred in that match for Sporting - quickly becoming United’s first-ever Portuguese player when he signed a contract before the 2003-04 season. His transfer fee of £12.24 million made Ronaldo at the time, the most expensive teenager in English football history.

The Old Trafford stadium which is otherwise called the ‘Theatre of Dreams’ for its marquee football players and record breaking success (United have won 20 English league titles) brings a wealth of expectation but Ronaldo exceeded his. Forming an indomitable partnership with Wayne Rooney (now the captain of United), these two were considered to be the brightest prospects in English football. Both Rooney and Ronaldo are recipients of the Professional Footballers’ Association Young Player of the Year award. Ronaldo subsequently went on to become United’s first Ballon d’Or winner since United’s George Best in 1968. The Ballon d’Or is universally recognised as football’s most prestigious individual honour. Ronaldo is widely considered to be United’s greatest player in his era. According to Ferguson, Ronaldo is the best football player he has seen - Ferguson is now 74 years of age.

text.headline: Cristiano Ronaldo: Fulfilling his childhood ambition
text.text:
Meant to join Real Madrid ahead of the 2008-2009 campaign only to stay with United for one last season, Ronaldo joined Madrid for a mammoth transfer free worth £80 million late in 2009. Ever since he could remember, Ronaldo dreamed of becoming a Real Madrid football player. Ronaldo is Real Madrid’s top goal scorer of all-time and is still playing for them. He has played under world class managers such as Zinedine Zidane and José Mourinho, with the latter winning an incredible 21 trophies across four different countries.

Ronaldo competes in La Liga BBVA, the same league Lionel Messi is in. Football analysts have constantly spoken about their rivalry and how they push each other to enormous heights football has never witnessed before. Once born in poverty, Ronaldo according to Forbes magazine is the world’s highest paid athlete.

text.headline: Luis Suarez: From Street Sweeper to Treble Winner
text.text:
Perhaps the most polarising figure in football today: Luis Suarez was born in Montevideo, Uruguay’s capital, to a family stricken by poverty. A cult hero in his home country; Suarez represents the word pelota, of which the direct translation is “ball”. To Uruguay, their favourite son is not a footballer; he’s a master of kicking a football in the street who managed to make it on the biggest stage of them all. An incident in the Uruguayan youth football league; when Suarez was fifteen years of age, illustrates the kind of turmoil Suarez grew up within; and the desire he had to play football. Allegedly a hotbed of systemic corruption, Uruguayan football came under the scope of mafias and cartels; so much so that when Suarez was sent off for headbutting a referee in a youth league semi-final, referee Luis Larranaga was threatened by the Uruguay’s head of youth football to change the post-match report. When a journalist broke the story of the intimidation, he was the subject of a failed hit and run from the head of youth football; who was sent to prison for the botched hit. 

When a small Dutch club in the Netherlands’ top football division named Groningen gave him his European break: it was his path to getting away from Uruguay and fulfilling his prestigious talent. Soon enough he was brought to Ajax; where he scored 81 goals in 110 games, was named Dutch Player of the Year in 2010, and had his first European controversy attached to his name when he bit an opponent in play.

text.headline: Luis Suarez: Liverpool's Talisman
text.text:
In January of 2011, Suarez transferred to Liverpool for £22.8 million pounds. It was Liverpool’s record transfer fee; the most they’d ever paid for a player – for a matter of hours, that is, until they forked out £35 million pounds for Andy Carroll. After scoring on his debut, Suarez took a season to enter his peak, but it was during the end of the 2012/13 season in which the Uruguayan began to shine. 

The following season he won the PFA player of the year and tied Cristiano Ronaldo for the most goals scored in Europe; despite being suspended in the first four games of the season due to another biting incident. He scored 31 goals in 33 games and nearly guided Liverpool to their first English title in 25 years. Due to that immense scoring record, Suarez won the Premier League player of the year and was found (by a Bloomberg study) to be the most influential player in Europe. His other-worldly form (being Europe’s best player) meant he would finally get his dream move to Barcelona.

text.headline: Luis Suarez: The World's BEst Striker
text.text:
The fee paid to Liverpool by Barcelona was £65 million; the 3rd highest fee ever paid for a footballer; and the most ever paid by Barcelona; seen as the world’s biggest club. It set the precedent for a galactic spending spree in the following seasons; when Napoli, Real Madrid and Manchester United all followed suit by breaking the £65 million pound barrier. 

When Luis Suarez moved to Barcelona; there were 7 players – including Luis Suarez – for whom more than £50 million was spent on in the history of football. Two years later; that number has doubled; now there are 15 players for whom £50 million or more has been spent on. Suarez was one of the first players whose transfer heralded the significant amount of money flowing through football.

text.headline: Zinedine Zidane: Zizou's Beginnings
text.text:
Nicknamed “Zizou”, the midfield magician many herald as one of the greatest players of all time was born in Marseille, in Southern France, to two Algerian refugees who fled to France before the Algerian War. He was born in 1972 – and was playing football by aged 5 in the main square of his small, unassuming town. His first move to a professional club was to French club Cannes; initially for a six week stay; although he ended up staying at the club for four years. According to Jean Varraud, the former player who discovered Zidane, “He’d go past one, two, three, five, six players – it was sublime. His feet spoke with the ball.” 

Zidane moved to Bordeaux in the 1992/93 season; and shortly following made his debut for the French national team; a side – and country – that he would become the face of. He was rejected by English Premier League teams like Newcastle and Blackburn for the price of £1.2 million before the beginning of the 1996 season because they thought he wasn’t to Premier League standard. At the end of that season, he won Ligue 1’s player of the season.

text.headline: Zinedine Zidane: The Best in Europe
text.text:
After impressing for both Bordeaux and France, Zidane chose to move to Juventus in 1996; and had an immediate impact. Juventus won the 1996/97 Serie A title and made the Champions League final that season; where Zidane infamously “went missing” during the final. 

Zidane would go on to win another Serie A title, and follow it up by being named FIFA Player of the Year and winning the Ballon D’Or; the prestigious award for Europe’s best player. His ascent to the top was complete: slightly marred by the first of his controversies when he head-butted a Hamburger SV player in the Champion’s League group stages. Nevertheless; he was known as the best midfielder in the world; and would be the subject of the most ludicrous fee of all time.

text.headline: Zinedine Zidane: Madrid's Superstar
text.text:
In 2001, Real Madrid paid £46.6 million to Juventus to procure the best footballer in the world. At the time, the transfer fee was gargantuan. In Italian terms; it was a fee of 150 billion Italian Lire. In today’s relative terms; adjusted for the fact that the average player cost significantly less in 2001, Zidane would today cost £75 million pounds; a fee that ranks him alongside the other members of this list. That’s how big Zidane was; one of the world’s best. He proved it too; scoring one of the greatest ever Champions League goals in the final of the 2002 tournament; leading Madrid to one of their most infamous wins – 2-1 over Bayer Leverkusen.

Zidane helped Madrid win consecutive La Liga titles in 2002 and 2003, and was named FIFA World Player of the Year for the third time. He was also voted the greatest European footballer of the past 50 years in 2004, as voted by fans. He may have been the greatest midfielder of the last 50 years; and the money paid for Zinedine Zidane certainly backs that up.
